title: Make codesandbox for docs
body:
Extracting this out of #142 into an issue to worry about later.

Many [software docs or home pages](https://tanstack.com/table/v8) have a CodeSandbox/StackBlitz/etc that let prospective users demo the package or whatever right from their browser, without having to install anything. The user can edit files and code, and a preview window will immediately show the results, sort of like a REPL. This would be great to have in the new docs as a "playground", so users can see how it works without even cloning the repo.

Unfortunately, these services don't seem to have SSG support; only JavaScript support. CodeSandbox does have a thing called a "container sandbox" that can run a Node environment, but idk if we could rig that to run a Ruby Jekyll build command.

An alternative that Dave Bunten mentioned is using GitHub codespaces. You can open a repo directly into a codespace, and apparently codespaces support Docker images, which are building for local previewing anyway.

What we need though is for it to be as simple and quick for the user as possible. Ideally, the user would click a link to open this repo in a codespace, then the `bundle jekyll exec serve` and `cite.py` processes would start running (either automatically or with a click of a button), then a preview window would also open up in a new tab with port forwarding.

title: Truly relative URLs (relative to current file/page) not supported

comments.body:
On further thought, I think this is something we won't implement. My reasoning:

- A URL can be specified in many places: `_data`, `.md` front matter, component parameters, in raw markdown, etc. When "relativizing" the URL, it will be relative to the place the URL is _consumed_, not the place it is _defined_. Maybe I could make the relativizing method smart enough to determine the place of definition, but it would be complicated and brittle.
- I envision this adding more confusion to users. For example, a user could see a `../image.jpg` link in a `_data` file and understandably think it refers an image one folder up (in the root), but really when that data file gets consumed/listed, it's in a sub-page like `/team/join` and so it's actually going to refer to an image in `/team`. They would have to look at a completely different part of the site/repo to see where that data is consumed. 
- Data and collections can be consumed in multiple different places. A common example of this is `citations.yaml`, where you might display only a small sub-set of noteworthy papers on your `/research` page, but display the entire list on `/cv` or a bio page. Because of this, relative links in data and collections could now refer to different files each time they are consumed. I suppose this could be considered a feature, but I think it's more likely to lead to insidious user frustration.
- Where this would be most useful is when you have a lot of nesting and sub-folders, but I don't think most people do this.

Instead I will add a clear note about this in the docs saying that all links to pages/images/etc. within the repo must be relative to the root, not relative to the current file.

But I could go either way on this, so if there are more users who want this, we could reopen this issue. So far it seems no one else has encountered or complained about not being able to do relative paths.

@d33bs your thoughts would be appreciated.

@vincerubinetti - thank you for the thorough notes and thoughts above! I agree that a clear note within the docs seems appropriate given what you mention. Depending on documentation structure, maybe an "FAQ" or placeholder issue with a related challenges when a relative path has been used (for ex. "Why aren't my images appearing?") and the solution could be helpful (this is only a suggestion).

body:
Sparked by this PR, where a relative path with `..`s caused image links to break:
https://github.com/CU-DBMI/set-website/pull/8/files

The "workaround" is to just say that users must always specify urls relative to the root of their repo. This is OK, but not ideal. It lacks flexibility and will definitely catch more people off guard in the future. It should work just like paths regularly do in HTML or any other directory system.

This is because I'm using the built-in Jekyll/Liquid filter `relative_url` in all of my components. However, this filter doesn't actually resolve relative urls, it just prepends `baseurl` to them.

See this issue for a discussion:
https://github.com/jekyll/jekyll/issues/6360

We can get the directory that the component is being used from with `page.dir`. Then we can use one of the solutions listed in that issue, either the plugin one or the gist/include one.

https://github.com/benbalter/jekyll-relative-links ?

title: Significant changes/refactoring/doc updates
body:
Basically a complete re-write of the template.

Summary of changes: simpler configuration, more automation, more customization/flexibility, more components, new docs, new look.

---

## Documentation

### Make dedicated docs site and repo

I need to bite the bullet on this. GitHub wiki is just not sufficient. Even I as the maintainer find it cumbersome and difficult to navigate and find things in the docs.

With the docs in a separate repo, when I update the template in a PR, I can link to the PR in the docs repo that updates the docs accordingly. Having the docs in a separate repo seems to be standard practice right now. It's no longer collocated with the template repo, but it offers too many benefits.

Needs:

- WYSIWYG editor (absolute must, at least for initial bulk rewrite)
- Search functionality (extremely important for users to find things and not give up)
- Sidebar navigation
- Produces plain markdown
- Sync with GitHub repo easily
- Ability to have some basic components, like switchable tabs, iframe embeds, tables, code blocks, etc
- Convenient linking between pages

Options:

- GitBook
- Bookstack
- Wiki.js
- Archbee
- Slite
- Docusaurus
- Docsify
- Algolia DocSearch

GitBook seems to be the best choice, despite it's free limitation of one user at a time.

### Is this template right for me?

Need big emphasis right at the start of who this template is for and how it compares to similar solutions.

- Key parts of target audience (other tech involved, but these are the most critical):
  - markdown editing
  - git/code/repositories
  - GitHub
  - GitHub Pages hosting (free, but source code can't be private without paying!!!)
  - Jekyll based template
- Alternatives:
  - GUI-based
    - Wowchemy and wowchemy/starter-hugo-research-group
    - Squarespace
    - Wix
    - Webflow
  - static/code-based
    - alshedivat/al-folio
    - academicpages/academicpages.github.io
    - photonlines/Research-Lab-Website
- Comparison:
  - Automatic citations using Manubot is biggest feature
  - Code based
  - Git tracking
  - Less components/visual flexibility, but you can customize fully with coding knowledge
  - We work hard to make our template as good as other static templates.

### High level first

Focus more on high level overview, and less on "under-the-hood" and "how it works".

- Organize info more like [modern docs](https://vitejs.dev/guide/).
- Put support front-and-center. Big tiles/links for making issues and discussions on front page. Emphasize that issues are for when the user thinks they've discovered a bug, and discussions are for when they need help. Emphasize short response time to issues!
- Focus more on common tasks and FAQs, like the first tasks users will want to or should do. E.g. How to use my own logo and share thumbnail.
- Explain general repo folder/file structure. Make clear which are "under-the-hood" and which are your content.
- Get rid of "Tips" page and put each tip front-and-center where applicable.
- Focus more on example walkthroughs where applicable, especially with citations.
- Provide actual template update instructions rather than just linking to stack overflow post.
- Instruct users on proper links. Must be relative to root. When to use Jekyll's built-in `link` component.

### Make different setup options clear

The only setup option that should really remain after all of these improvements is template vs fork. Make very clear table comparison of pros and cons of each. Use consistent terminology: "generated" for "use as template" or "forked" for "forking".

### Make different editing workflows clear

Don't discount local building and previewing. Right now I'm trying to hide this as a more "advanced" workflow, but realistically people will eventually need to do things locally for bigger bulk changes. Need to put "GitHub.com" and "local" front-and-center as the two ways to do things. Emphasize the former is good for smaller changes, latter is good for larger. Don't discount GitHub's new .dev and "codespace" editors!! Easy way to make bulk, local/VSCode-like changes right in the browser.

### More comprehensive component docs

- Offer more comprehensive and various examples (especially important for list component, citations, etc).
- Use tables for parameter definitions.
- Consistently format/show value types and defaults.

### Simplify citations page

- Focus less on the under-the-hood (adequately explained by comments in code), and more on user workflows. Examples:
  - Using ORCID and overriding a specific paper detail
  - Using ORCID and attaching a custom field to all papers
  - Using the list component to display all citations
  - Using the list component to display only ORCID citations
  - etc.
- Simplify diagram. Should just explain the differences between plugins and sources, and how they end up in citations which are then read by the template and displayed with citation components. Provide actual file entry examples in diagram.
- Don't split into "basic" and "advanced". Assume many people will want to use ORCID/etc. plugins, and treat then as "first class".
- Make clear that ORCID is for pulling in sources automatically, and sources is for listing out manually. Past confused users put both ORCID and sources, ending up with many duplicates.
- Use Mermaid for diagram.

### Move gallery

Move gallery to docs repo. Can make the the screenshots a lot nicer this way. Put in grid of cards. Have link to issue to submit your own.

## Template

### Address versioning

Since this is a template, not a package that you install, versioning is kind of hard. It is made even harder when user's use the "template" option as opposed to the "forking" option, because no git information gets transferred (history, tags, etc.). So far I've been using git tags to "version" things, but that's very informal and insufficient.

Use `CITATION.cff` as the source of truth for the version. This file will get copied to users' repos, and is there for them to cite if they need to reference the template.

Add a changelog file, which is removed from the user's copy of the template. Follow common-changelog.org.

Have GitHub action that checks PRs (only on the template itself) to make sure the version, date, and changelog has been updated, and automatically creates a tag and release with info from changelog.

### Look and feel

- More neutral, less annoying stock photos. Get rid of dog placeholder stuff.
- Redesign header and headings.
- Touch up component designs.
- More detailed footer with sitemap, address, etc https://www.cuanschutz.edu/

### General changes

- Remove favicon variations and folder. Use just one in images folder for simplicity.
- Add fields to citations:
    - `description` for hand-written markdown description.
    - Show `id` in citation component, not just on hover of thumbnail.
- More theme variables
    - Header size and layout
    - Logo size
    - Google Fonts choice
- More flexible page layout.
    - Turn "two col" component into "n-col" component.
    - Turn gallery component into generic grid component for things like cards, citations, blog post excerpts, etc.
- Change behavior of link default icons/text/etc? Confusing to have to put blank string to get defaults?
- Get rid of built-in color palettes and just link to Tailwind and Material color palettes.

### Tech changes

- Update all GitHub Actions, Gems, and other packages to their latest versions.
- Make all js scripts modules.
- CSS better practices:
    - De-nest. Simple class names so easier to identify.
    - Use inset.
- Make use of Jekyll plugins to write custom Liquid filters for cleaner under-the-hood code.
- Change FA5 icon names to FA6 names.
- Format all files with Prettier Liquid plugin.

### New components and formatting

- Float component for wrapping text around images.
- Mathjax, Mermaid diagrams, videos, etc. with Jekyll Spaceship.
- Light/dark mode with toggle.

### Separate template from content better

Will help visually cue users what they need to edit for their content, vs what they'd need to edit if they were doing deep customization. Will also help with resolving merge conflicts when updating the template.

In general, prefix "under-the-hood" folders (e.g. `/auto-cite`, `/css`, `/js`) with `_` or `.`, and leave normal folders (starting with a letter) for the contentful pages of the site.

### Separate GitHub Actions workflows better

There will be several separate GitHub Actions workflows. Separate tasks (updating citations, rebuilding live site, etc) from triggers (on push to main, on cron, etc) to reduce complexity, duplicate runs, infinite loops, and more.

### Issue/Discussion/PR checks

PR template (only for template itself): "Warning, you're about to open this PR against the template itself, you probably meant to open it against your main website repo."

For issues, direct user to right place: issue (user thinks they've found a bug), discussion (user needs help), docs issue, and general issue (as a fallback).

Issue template:

- Checkbox, user has already looked through docs and existing issues/discussions.
- Textbox, link to user repo for reproducibility and troubleshooting.
- Textbox, version of their template in `CITATION.cff`.

## Citations

### Simplify plugins

Get rid of config. No specifying input or output files. Instead, prefix files for which plugin they need to go to, e.g. `sources-2021.yaml` or `orcid-alumni.yaml`. All plugins "enabled" by default, and scan for appropriate files. No error when they can't find any input files, because user might not be using any.

### Rework caching

Surprisingly difficult problem to solve cleanly. You have different plugins, override fields, rich details, mutations, adding/changing/removing entries and overrides, separate time-consuming network requests, etc. There's a lot of potential for edge cases that I run into whenever I try to do a clever or efficient solution. Need an elegant, simple, robust solution.

~I think a better solution is to keep manubot's original response (before overrides) in tact in the `citations.yaml` file, and keep that as the in-repo, tracked, cross-context "cache". We can separate this from the rich detail and override fields by using subkeys in `citations.yaml`. Then in components that read the `citations.yaml` file, we'll have to do something like `citation.override.title || citation.manubot.title || "No title"` for each field. It makes it more verbose for consuming the citations, but it keeps all the original data cleanly separated and "immutable". Having these things separated in subkeys in `citations.yaml` doesn't mean they have to be subkeys in the input files though, so it can still be convenient for users.~

~On further thought, the above is maybe not desirable. It would make the citation and list components (importantly, the filtering feature) much more complex. Also, if the user wants to do any custom looping through the citations data, it becomes more complicated and confusing, with all the subkeys.~

~I think it's possible to have a special sub-key called `manubot` or `original` that stores only keys that Manubot would return AND are going to be overridden by the user, giving the script a way to restore the full original (from the previous run) Manubot response before any overrides.~

~Instead, just have a separate Manubot cache.yaml file in the cite folder that saves the Manubot response, untouched by any overrides. The downside of this is that it duplicates a lot of data. The upside is that it's much simpler, less error prone, and sensical (it's clear why it's there, and it's only for the Manubot part of the citing process).~

Just use `diskcache` and keep it simple(er). #123

### New features

- Have explicit field to determine which file source came from in case the user wants to filter by this rather than attaching fields manually. (We had this for a short time when I was experimenting with different caching approaches).
- Allow users to apply rich details and/or overrides to a particular source from a meta source in a `sources.yaml` file by id. E.g., get all papers from ORCID `XXX`, but for paper `id:123`, correct the title to `"blah blah"`.
- Write Google Scholar and NCBI plugins in addition to ORCID plugin.
- Deduplicate `citations.yaml` by id, except if id is blank, because then we're assuming user is inputting their citation data manually.
- Rewrite entire code for cleanliness.

## Setup

Overall, the goal is to remove as much setup as humanly possible, and make things just one-click or one-install.

### Switch to GitHub Actions as source of Pages

Historically, if you wanted to have GitHub Pages build your site automatically with no setup, you had to play by their rules. It had to be Jekyll, and you could only use certain [white-listed gems and Jekyll plugins](https://pages.github.com/versions/). Then with the introduction of GitHub Actions, could you have a workflow to automatically build a site however you wanted to, and push the result to the `gh-pages` branch, by-passing these restrictions.

To keep this template as simple as possible and avoid having a separate `gh-pages` branch that might confuse people, I stuck strictly to the "vanilla" pages experience above. However, things have changed since then. Now GitHub has a beta feature where you can build a Pages site from an Action rather than from a branch. You just give it an Actions workflow to tell GitHub how to build your app, and it runs that when it needs to (changes pushed to `main`, site domain or repo name changed, etc).

This opens up a whole world of possibilities that is too good to pass up. We will be able to use any Jekyll packages, e.g. the multi-language one. We could even write our own Jekyll plugins. It's well worth adding some extra workflow files.

### Automatic setup and updates

Users constantly have trouble with manually setting `baseurl`. They don't understand what it's for, when to do it, or even that it's necessary.

Automatic setup when the user first starts their repo:

- Create empty `gh-pages` branch
- Remove unneeded files, e.g. testbed, changelog, etc.
- Personalize the readme, Jekyll config, and homepage for the user based on their GitHub user name and other metadata.

Automatic update when GitHub Pages builds site (when the repo name changes, when the custom domain changes, or when Pages is first enabled) (`workflows: [pages-build-deployment]`):

- Update user's readme with the latest link to their deployed site.
- Rebuild site with new `baseurl`, retrieved automatically and reliably with [`actions/configure-pages`](https://github.com/actions/configure-pages).

### Use GitHub instead of Netlify for deploy previews

Setting up Netlify is a huge barrier and time-sink to getting started with the template. Linking Netlify to your GitHub account and repo takes a long time and is a confusing process.

We can make use of [`rossjrw/deploy-pr-preview`](https://github.com/rossjrw/pr-preview-action).

title: Show last authors in citation component
body:
Currently the citation component (in "rich" design mode) truncates the list of authors, as this list can be very long. This sometimes hides the last author(s), which are usually significant and should be shown.

The way this works now is just by letting the browser truncate the text past 1 line with ellipsis. Unfortunately, there is no built-in way to do ["middle...ellipsis"](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/831552/ellipsis-in-the-middle-of-a-text-mac-style), so I'd have to write a new javascript plugin to do this.

If enough people want this, I can add the javascript and extra complexity, though it still won't look as nice or consistent as the current solution.

Another option is to just always display all the authors. You can do this by removing the `truncate` class here:
https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/blob/main/_includes/citation.html#L52

If users want it, I can also add `truncate-n` utility classes that will truncate to `n` number of lines. I guess this could be useful to show last authors most of the time (if the author list is short), but still prevent enormously tall citations when the author list is huge.

body:
From this comment:

 > Is there a way to get these links to open in a new window/tab, e.g. by setting `target="_blank"` on the links?
> 
> UPDATE: I looked into it a bit and it's possible to change Jekyll's renderer from GitHub-flavored markdown to a different style, "Kramdown", that allows you to add arbitrary attributes to tags, but supposedly it can change the site's rendering in subtle ways. Maybe it's best to just leave the links as-is to avoid changing the renderer, but I figured I'd leave a record of it all the same. (reference, https://stackoverflow.com/a/71373125/346905)

It will not be good/possible to do this for all links, but for components (gallery, member portrait, button, etc), we control the html and can put in target blank.

However I don't really like doing this, especially for apps where the user isn't entering in any data and thus has no risk of losing things when navigating away. I prefer to be able to open a link in the current tab (regular left click) if I want, and not be forced to open a new tab (like a middle click).

If we did want to do this... it'd probably make sense to open in a new tab if the url was an external one. Since Jekyll doesn't have built in "functions" per se, in every component where there's a link, I'd have to do a few checks (starts with http, https, mailto, etc), which would get repetitive. Instead, I might actually want to just do that in a small javascript plugin.

title: Hyphen in member name not showing in member page heading or tab title

comments.body:
Thank you for reporting this. I'm surprised/embarrassed I didn't catch this. I will be pushing a fix shortly, but in the meantime (and if you don't want to go through the difficult process of updating your version of the template), you can do this to fix it. Go into `_layouts/member.html` and change the `

` line to: ```html

{{ page.name | default: page.title }}

``` This will use the `name` you put in the member's `.yaml` front matter for the top of the page (with the filename as a fallback if name is not specified).

Awesome, thanks for the quick response. That fixed it. I did the same for

```
{%- capture text -%}
  {{ page.name | page.title }}'s papers
{%- endcapture -%}
```
in the same layout. The only other place I see that this occurs is in the name of the page (i.e. the text you see on the browser tab). Thanks again!

Another good catch! I've also looked through the code, and believe I've caught all this places where this might occur. Take a look at this hot-fix commit to see all of the things you should probably change:

https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/commit/506639e0ee2bf403c503991fb17cbe3cfbbe9d43

Ah, I missed something else with that last hot fix, apologies. Please also see this commit:

https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/commit/c20535e4375bf7c9cdea0fafcf9912cf6cd10d18

This is needed because apparently, if the user hasn't set `name` in the page front matter, Jekyll auto-populates the `page.name` field with the filename for some reason, usually `index.md`. This change attempts to detect whether the user or jekyll has set `page.name`.

title: Add workflow to rerun auto-cite periodically
body:
For the case of listing normal sources, this is a process that the site-maintainer is doing manually. Your lab publishes a cool new paper, you do a PR to your site to add it to the list.

For the case of metasources, like ORCID, these will get updated with new papers at random, without the maintainer necessarily knowing. It'd be nice to have a way to periodically refetch metasources to see if new publications have been added.

We could set up a github actions cron job that re-runs the auto-cite process every week/month/etc. It might actually be as simple as adding a `cron` trigger to the [current workflow](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/blob/main/.github/workflows/auto-cite.yaml). There will still be the classic issue of the cron job stopping after X days of repo inactivity, which we'll need to address.

IIRC, there's also a way to make a github action that is triggerable by the click of a button in the actions tab (still a manual user interaction, but much easier for the user and easier to instruct them on than doing a commit/PR).

title: Ignore manubot cite errors when source is from a metasource?

comments.body:
This is under the purview of Manubot (and will likely get transferred there if it is a valid issue), but I will try to help.

I tried running Manubot (with a fresh/upgraded install) on this citation, and it does not understand the identifier prefix `eid`:

```
manubot cite eid:2-s2.0-85041428367

Generating csl_item for 'eid:2-s2.0-85041428367' failed due to a NotImplementedError:
Manubot does not know how to generate a csl_item for 'eid:2-s2.0-85041428367'
```

You can see what prefixes Manubot supports in this file of its source code:
https://github.com/manubot/manubot/blob/main/manubot/cite/handlers.py
There is `civic.eid` and `egid`, but not `eid`.

> however these are not from my quote list and apparently are from another user using the bot

Where did you see this identifier being used? For a statement like this, please provide a link or reference so we can help you.

Okay I took a look at your failed github actions workflow run here:
https://github.com/LaBiOmicS/labiomics.github.io/runs/7062873948?check_suite_focus=true

It seems like the `eid` reference is getting generated from the ORCID plugin. Maybe this is what you were referring to when you said "another user using the bot"?

It looks like these are the types of identifiers that the ORCID api (and thus the ORCID plugin in this template) might output, not all of which are supported by Manubot: 

https://github.com/ORCID/orcid-model/blob/578cd716cb7222f9a7adfbfdd8a8c94aad254b7e/src/main/java/org/orcid/jaxb/model/message/WorkExternalIdentifierType.java

Hi,

So I believe the real issue/question here is regarding throwing errors when Manubot can't cite something.

Currently, if Manubot fails to cite something, I throw an error and stop the process, because I figured that this is something that the user would definitely want to know about. It usually means that the user has entered a invalid paper id or something.

However in the case of ORCID, the user isn't directly generating the list of papers, ORCID is. And ORCID might be returning types of paper identifiers that Manubot doesn't know how to cite. Should I still throw an error in this case? Probably not.

I've renamed this issue accordingly. I think I'll change the behavior to letting cite errors pass only if it is a metasource like ORCID.

title: How are the tags of the publications generated?

comments.body:
Yes, you provide the tags manually. These are not something Manubot can (or should) generate automatically. You can choose what tags are most important to your website visitors, and categories your papers accordingly.

See this page of the docs:
https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Citations

In `sources.yaml`, just provide a `tag` field alongside the paper's `id` with a list of strings.
Thank you very much for your quick response!

body:
Hi,
I want ask about how the tags of the publications are generated. After running auto-cite, I didn't get the tags in the output file citations.yaml. Are they manually added? Thank you!

title: Package-ify this template?

comments.body: Probably in the minority but 👎
Realistically, I don't think this is something that will be possible. I don't think Jekyll is really set up to do this cleanly. Perhaps other SSGs would be.
Related: #278

body:
There are a few high-level frustrations with this template that I wish I could improve:

1. It is very hard and cumbersome to update a website to the latest version of the template, even for me who knows every file and line of code intimately. Perhaps this is less of a problem as the template becomes more stable and changes less, thus avoiding the need to update. It's also hard to know what version of the template you're on. If the template were, for example, simply a package you install in your Gem (Ruby) package file, with a SemVer number, it'd be easier to get users to stay up to date, and easier to troubleshoot problems.
2. Everything in the template is exposed to the user. I'd guess that 75% or more of the files and code could be called "under-the-hood", code that most users would never need to edit. This is good for power users who want to customize things, but is just a source of complexity, confusion, and most importantly *distraction* for users who just want to focus on their website content (most of our audience?).

I'm not exactly sure what the solution would be, but my instinct is that the template would be a Gem (Ruby package), and would "hide" as much of its code in there as possible. A user would then just install the package in a blank Jekyll site (we would still give instructions), or we could keep a very minimal Jekyll boilerplate repo with the package already installed.

---

But before pursuing this, I'd like to know what users want. **If you're a user reading this, please vote**:

- 👍 I want things as simple as possible so I can focus just on my website content. I don't care about customizing *deep* functionality of the template, I just need some very basic surface-level customization. I want to be able to easily update my version of the template when new features and bug fixes come out.
- 👎 I want absolute control. I want to be able to change any line of code in the template, including things like: the behavior of auto-citations, the exact look and feel of components (beyond high-level "theming"), etc. It is okay that updating my version of the template for new features and bug fixes will be difficult.

title: Allow omitting `id` in `sources.yaml`
body:
Currently the auto-city Python script expects there to be an `id` field in every source entry. Weird things will happen if not.

However, some users will want to bypass Manubot completely and fill out all citation data manually, which may mean that they either do not have or do not provide an id for the source. The script should support this case.

title: Failing to add manual references to citation

comments.body:
This is more of a Manubot question but I will try to help.

The first thing to note is that Manubot is not just a single thing, it's a suite/ecosystem. It has several tools, and different workflows under which you'd use them. In this template, we're only using the `manubot cite` functionality. The ["manual references"](https://github.com/manubot/manubot#manual-references-1) readme section that you linked is under the "Pandoc filter" functionality. 

`manubot cite` does have a `--bibliography` flag where you can provide a file for manual citation data. But the template [doesn't use](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/blob/main/auto-cite/util.py#L141-L149) this flag, because there is already a way to provide manual citation directly with the template. This page of the docs explains how:

https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Citations#basic-use

Whatever the content of your `files/refs/dance.json` file is, just move it to `sources.yaml` like this:

```yaml
- id: doi:1234
  title: Some Paper Title
  author: Yang Lu
  publisher: Cold Spring Harbor
```

(Note that for now, due to [this oversight](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/issues/117), please make sure you put a dummy `doi:` in the id field even if you don't have a real one for the paper. Hopefully I will address this in a few days.)

> An alternative question is how to add conference proceeding papers (e.g. ICML) without any DOI information? 

Regarding this question, again see [this section of the docs](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Citations#sourcesyaml). Manubot supports many ways to cite a paper besides `doi`. If the ICML provides any kind of established reference number for the proceeding papers (maybe `ISSN`?), try using that. Then if that doesn't work, you can also use a `url`. Then as a last resort, you can manually input citation data as described in my comment above.
Hi @batmen-lab , did this answer your question?
The question was perfectly answered and problem solved! Thanks!

Here is what I did: I add a new record with "id: raw:files/refs/dance.json" where the CSL-JSON is manually written and put under the local files/refs/ folder, as suggested by https://github.com/manubot/manubot#manual-references-1. title: Show Manubot citation error

comments.body:
I was mistaken. This already happens. For example, if you enter in a valid identifier *type*, but an invalid id *number*, Manubot will still print out error text from within this `try` block. For example, doing `id: doi:10.1016/j.csbj.2020.05.0172` (a real doi with a `2` accidentally added to the end) gives you this:
log ``` VincesMacBookPro:lab-website-template rubinetv$ python3 ./auto-cite/auto-cite.py COMPILING LIST OF SOURCES TO CITE RUNNING SOURCES PLUGIN ../_data/sources.yaml doi:10.1016/j.csbj.2020.05.0172 doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1007128 doi:10.7554/eLife.32822 Got 3 sources GENERATING CITATIONS FOR SOURCES Can't find ../_data/citations.yaml Source 1 of 3 - doi:10.1016/j.csbj.2020.05.0172 Using Manubot to generate new citation ## ERROR Error fetching metadata for doi:10.1016/j.csbj.2020.05.0172. Invalid response from https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csbj.2020.05.0172: Error: DOI Not Found
HOME  | HANDBOOK  | FACTSHEETS  | FAQs  |  RESOURCES  | USERS  | NEWS  | MEMBERS AREA

DOI Not Found

 

10.1016/j.csbj.2020.05.0172

 

This DOI cannot be found in the DOI System. Possible reasons are:

  • The DOI is incorrect in your source. Search for the item by name, title, or other metadata using a search engine.
  • The DOI was copied incorrectly. Check to see that the string includes all the characters before and after the slash and no sentence punctuation marks.
  • The DOI has not been activated yet. Please try again later, and report the problem if the error continues.
 

You may report this error to the responsible DOI Registration Agency using the form below.

Your Email Address:
Additional Information About the Error:

The DOI entered is not a valid DOI: it should start with 10 followed by a dot,
and contain a slash with no preceding whitespace.

The email address entered is invalid.

Please contact us if you wish to report this anyway.
 
DOI Resolution Documentation
®, DOI®, DOI.ORG®, and shortDOI® are trademarks of the International DOI Foundation.
## CRITICAL Failure: exiting with code 1 due to logged errors Manubot could not generate citation ```
However, if you put in a completely invalid Manubot identifier like `doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2203.13946`, as happened in https://github.com/greenelab/greenelab.com/pull/45, Manubot logs a *warning*, not an *error*. Therefore I will just increase (decrease?) the Manubot log level to `WARNING`.

body:
In https://github.com/greenelab/greenelab.com/pull/45, there was an invalid source identifier, but the automatic citation process just said "Manubot could not generate citation". This is obviously unhelpful.

I believe I hid all output from the Manubot process, since it generates a lot of text that would clutter the logs. However, it needs to show whatever helpful message Manubot has when it throws an error.

title: Automatic citations not working when doing a pull request from a fork

comments.body:
I've tried many things.

- Alternatives to `stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action`
- `stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action` options
- `pull_request` and/or `pull_request_target` triggers
- GitHub repo settings

None have seemed to work consistently. I must unfortunately conclude that, at least for now, we have to just say that automatic citations only work from a branch.

body:
Several people have had trouble with automatic citations when doing PRs from forks:

https://github.com/greenelab/greenelab.com/pull/45
https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/issues/96

Auto-citations is the main feature of the template, so these issues are unacceptable.

This appears to be some kind of permissions issue. When you open a pull request from a fork, that is essentially a third party stranger on GitHub that is trying to trigger a GitHub Actions workflow in your website repo that commits directly to it.

I've tried many things in the past to solve this, but nothing seems to work consistently. The solution may end up being that we tell people you *must* do PRs from branches, not forks. I'd rather have a strict limitation that works 100% of the time than a more flexible one that fails inconsistently and inexplicably.

Also, it'd be good to style the "selected" (searched for in the url) tag differently to show that it's active.

Also, make use of flex `gap` for tags (and everything else where appropriate) and get rid of `trim-v/h-margins` mixins.

Also, tags generated from `repo` seem to not have tooltips working, whereas manual tags do.

Also, add "clear search" button to `search-info` component.

Also, search box clear button icon not showing up?

comments.body: Found it! I needed to adjust `baseurl` in _config.yaml.

Thanks for testing @aschuerch .

Improper `baseurl` can cause a few issues, but I don't see how it could cause that issue. Could you give more information on what you were doing? Where is your website repo, what is the link to the Netlify preview build, what did you change `baseurl` to, etc. It might help other people debugging in the future.

Also, the issues that `baseurl` does cause aren't exactly obvious or intuitive. The docs have "configuring `baseurl`" pretty front and center, but they don't give a warning that failing to do so can cause unexpected errors. So I will add a generic message like that.

We attempted yesterday to further fill in the details for the site - overall a smooth process, for starters and github pro's alike. Once we're a bit further with the site I'll add it to your gallery.
The error that I made with setting the baseurl was that I didn't set it, and I think it is a good idea to add a generic message about unexpected errors.

I rewrote/reworked the getting started page to hopefully be a little clearer, and emphasize the importance of setting `baseurl`.

As for what caused it, I have only a vague idea. It might be related to how Jekyll/Sass looks for imports. Currently I do imports at the top of each SASS file like `@import "theme";`, and maybe Jekyll incorporates `baseurl` when looking for that import (idk why it would since this is happening at build-time, not at run-time). Maybe doing relative imports like `@import "./theme";` would fix it... I'll look into it at some point.

title: Address webaim accessibility issues
body:
Example:
https://wave.webaim.org/report#/https://www.waysciencelab.com/

Some things to correct:

- heading anchors should have an `aria-label` like `Perma-link to [this section]`
- presentational images in components like feature should have `role="presentation"` so screen readers know they can be skipped. in general, need to take a close look at all places where images can be and either bypass, or allow website maintainer to reliably add alt text. i know i've done this in a few places, but not all/enough.
- get rid of all font sizes < `1.0rem` and just round them up to 1 to hopefully avoid complaints about small font sizes from GSC
- add lang attr to html
- maybe make footer icons bigger for mobile touch accessibility

Run through Lighthouse for more.

title: Google search console - text too small to read, clickable elements too close together

comments.body:
You can safely ignore this. I'll elaborate more tomorrow but here's some related links:

https://web.dev/accessible-tap-targets/

https://search.google.com/test/mobile-friendly/result?utm_source=gws&utm_medium=onebox&utm_campaign=suit&id=XjFMPr_xUxkhmzCBmk1bbQ&url=https%3A%2F%2Fgreenelab.com%2F

https://webmasters.stackexchange.com/questions/127891/how-to-resolve-text-too-small-to-read-error-from-google-search-consoles-mobil?newreg=4d07206dbdba41e08de8aa1f0afe8a53

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57095841/google-says-text-too-small-to-read-but-no-info-about-recommended-font-size

Okay, so if you read the links above, you'll find some common complaints about these warnings. I encounter them a lot and find them to be invalid. Here are some reasons why.

When GSC gives you these errors, it doesn't give any helpful information. It doesn't tell you where the errors are occurring or what is causing them. They're not very actionable.

Google says they want at least `12px` for font sizes, yet we are definitely not using anything smaller than `14.4px`:  `16px` default `<html`> font size times `0.9rem` (smallest font size in any of the css styles) equals `14.4px`. Also, Chrome Lighthouse does not report any small text size issue. GSC is wrong.

Regarding clickable elements too close together, I'm assuming (again I can't be sure because GSC gives no info) that it's complaining about things like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8326331/138926578-1de15040-f4c5-463a-8361-607a9f307b74.png)

GSC seems to want at least a few pixels of space between any link or button. I get where they're coming from (see the links above), but I think they're misguided and not backed up by any hard research (my opinions aren't either, but I just say this to say that we shouldn't just trust them as fact). I purposefully make these links such that they have no margins (space) around them, but a large padding (click "hitbox"). This way, you don't get the annoying situation where you're trying to click on something but accidentally click on blank space between them, doing nothing. At least you always get a click on *something*, whichever you were closest to. I don't like links where you have to get super precise in order to click them. I submit that what matters is not the space between clickable items, but the absolute size of clickable items, such that people, even those on small mobile screens with motor deficiencies for example, can easily click them. Testing this template on mobile, it seems to me that the icons in the footer (which might be the most problematic) are still large enough to easily touch, though I might bump the size of them anyway just a little bit. But I do not think the spacing matters. This is also something that Lighthouse does not complain about. 🤷 

---

However, as a result of all this, I've opened #101 to solve some related accessibility issues. Look out for a major release coming soon (hopefully) that addresses these and perhaps makes some errors go away.

Thanks Vince!

title: Manual reference for publication?

comments.body:
I think this is more of a Manubot question. I believe the answer is that you'd just do `id: "url:http://ceur-ws.org/Vol-2976/"` in the `sources.yaml` file. Manubot supports many other identifier types other than `doi:`. This is talked about in the [lab website template doc page here](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Automatic-Citations#sourcesyaml).

If Manubot is not able to gather enough citation information from the url, you can just manually input information in `sources.yaml`, which is also talked about on [that docs page](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Automatic-Citations#sourcesyaml). Just make sure you get the field names and formats right. Look at `citations.yaml` to see what schema the template expects the information to be in.

Also I'm going to transfer this issue to the lab website template in case anyone else has it.
Thank you @vincerubinetti! Fingers crossed that it finds the pdf tolerable!

body:
The paper that was published in CEUR-WS has no DOI. For the COVID project, we created a manual reference. I wasn't sure what the best way to handle this would be for the website, so I wanted to check in with @vincerubinetti

<http://ceur-ws.org/Vol-2976/>
<http://ceur-ws.org/Vol-2976/paper-2.pdf>

title: Autocite errors

comments.body:
Update on manubot error: it seems to have resolved, in some unknown way. I am still struggling with the `git-auto-commit-action`.

I did two things that I know of, and perhaps one or more mysterious things.

## First attempt

```bash
# First, I tried running the preferred citation formatter, as specified in the action
python auto-cite/auto-cite.py
```

This ran into the same error as `bash cite.sh`.

## Second attempt

I noticed that my arxiv id was missing the version tag, so I fixed it in WayScience/waysciencelab.com/1@b52c1087288b5980c203c2d971ce6fde62e3d021 and reran `auto-cite.py`. I received the same error.

## Resolution of Manubot error

I then moved on to try to resolve the github action bug by testing several ideas found in https://github.com/stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action (they're documented in my PR), but none worked.

However, somewhere along the way I tried compiling citations again and it somehow worked! I do not believe I changed anything in the sources yaml, but I did reinstall manubot.

So, either reinstalling manubot worked _or_ somehow running the same code more than once resolved the manubot issue.

Regarding the Manubot cite errors, that is most likely an upstream error with Manubot itself or one of the services it relies on like Crossref. Did you try running Manubot directly like `manubot cite arxiv:2104.11364` at the time when it wasn't working? Also I don't think the version should matter.

In an effort to not confuse people, I tried to keep the logging of the auto-cite process as clean as possible, so I hid the actual text from the Manubot error. But if it would help, I could point to the place in the code where you could explicitly show the error Manubot threw when running auto-cite.

Also FYI, running `cite.sh` is just a shorthand for `python auto-cite/auto-cite.py`, so that will always be the same result.

Regarding the errors with the action. I see you're working from a fork of your website rather than a branch. Did you make sure to [enable GitHub actions on the fork repo before opening the pull request](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Get-Started#on-your-computer)? I'm looking through the errors in your github actions, and there's a lot of changes so it's hard to tell what happened. But usually that `pathspec` error occurs when the `stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action` doesn't have the permissions to write, which can happen when you're working from a fork and haven't enabled gh-actions before the pr.

One strange thing is you were getting an error about the input branch being `init`, and it doesn't look like you were setting that in the `stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action` or anything. Which btw, you should never need to customize the options for that; it's supposed to commit to the same branch that it's currently on (whatever branch triggered the workflow run, be that a straight commit to `main` or a pull request branch). I can't find anything about `init` in the `stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action` docs either.

Thanks @vincerubinetti !

> Did you try running Manubot directly like manubot cite arxiv:2104.11364 at the time when it wasn't working?

I did not.

> But if it would help, I could point to the place in the code where you could explicitly show the error Manubot threw when running auto-cite.

I think it might... perhaps adding `--verbose` flag functionality would do the trick. I actually just ran into this just now and received the following error:

```bash
COMPILING LIST OF SOURCES TO CITE

RUNNING SOURCES PLUGIN

  ../_data/sources.yaml

    Can't parse ../_data/sources.yaml. Make sure it's valid YAML.
```

It would have been helpful to know that line 196 was invalidating the YAML. (I am not sure if Manubot would tell you that by default)

> Did you make sure to enable GitHub actions on the fork repo before opening the pull request? But usually that pathspec error occurs when the stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action doesn't have the permissions to write, which can happen when you're working from a fork and haven't enabled gh-actions before the pr.

Pretty sure I did! But I am about to file a new PR, so we'll see if the errors persist.

Autocite failed in new pull request WayScience/waysciencelab.com#2

```bash
Run stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action@v4
  with:
    file_pattern: _data/citations.yaml
    commit_message: Generate citations
    push_options: --force
    branch: update-round-2
    repository: .
    commit_user_name: GitHub Actions
    commit_user_email: actions@github.com
    commit_author: gwaygenomics <gwaygenomics@users.noreply.github.com>
    skip_dirty_check: false
    skip_fetch: false
    disable_globbing: false
  env:
    pythonLocation: /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.7.11/x64
    LD_LIBRARY_PATH: /opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.7.11/x64/lib
From https://github.com/WayScience/waysciencelab.com
Started: bash /home/runner/work/_actions/stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action/v4/entrypoint.sh
 * [new branch]      main       -> origin/main
INPUT_REPOSITORY value: .
INPUT_STATUS_OPTIONS: 
INPUT_BRANCH value: update-round-2
error: pathspec 'update-round-2' did not match any file(s) known to git
Error: Invalid status code: 1
    at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (/home/runner/work/_actions/stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action/v4/index.js:17:19)
    at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:210:5)
    at maybeClose (internal/child_process.js:1021:16)
    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:283:5) {
  code: 1
}
Error: Invalid status code: 1
    at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (/home/runner/work/_actions/stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action/v4/index.js:17:19)
    at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:210:5)
    at maybeClose (internal/child_process.js:1021:16)
    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:283:5)
```

I'm still looking into this, but in the future, can you try doing pull requests from branches of the same repo instead of from a fork. 

`git-auto-commit` has had warnings in the past that forks may not work. With the instruction to enable github actions first, I was able to make it work consistently with a fork during my testing. But maybe that is no longer the case. Maybe there was a change to the action that made it stop working.

Just confirmed in WayScience/waysciencelab.com#7 that a PR from a branch enables the autocite action.

Thanks!

title: truncated titles and variation in citation format?

comments.body:
I'm guessing you're talking about entries like this one:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8326331/130493622-1017c1cc-c3de-43ee-89e2-7ee4242be570.png)

The template uses [Manubot](https://manubot.org/) to generate citation details (including fetching the title of the paper), which itself uses a few other tools and resources. Unfortunately sometimes there are errors with specific papers due to upstream issues that are out of our control.

Luckily, you can [override any arbitrary field](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Automatic-Citations) that you want from the input file to fix these (hopefully infrequent) errors. In your case (the screenshot above), in your `sources.yaml` file, you'd do this:

```yaml
- id: pmid:34067070
  title: Transcriptional Analysis of Coccidioides immitis Mycelia and Spherules by RNA Sequencing
  image: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/instance/8150946/bin/jof-07-00366-g001.jpg
  tags:
    - coccidioides
    - onygenales
    - RNA-seq
```

Regarding the citation style, right now this is somewhat hardcoded into the template. You'd have to change the lines of Python code here:
https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/blob/main/auto-cite/util.py#L163-L166

In the future if enough people request it we may add more flexible styling.

Got it - will do the manual override, I needed that!

And honestly the styling is low priority and not that important.

Cool, I'll close this issue for now.

If you're someone else stumbling on this issue and also want the ability to style the citations differently, give the original post above a 👍 so we know how in-demand the feature is.

tislab.org [has a page of projects](https://tislab.org/research/) where each project has a "project contact". It seems like all of these contacts are also people in their `_members` collection, where names/emails/phone numbers/etc are already defined. 

Instead of having to duplicate this info, it'd be cool if they could just refer to a member profile like `{% include member-card.html member="anne-thessen" %}`, and then the details get pulled in automatically, leaving only one source of truth for the details (in the member's file, e.g. `_members/anne-thessen.md`).

Not sure exactly the best way to implement this yet.

title: Add sub-page drop downs to navigation bar in header

comments.body:
Unfortunately, for now, I've decided to not implement this feature because 1) only one person has requested it so far, 2) it would add significant code complexity for me and configuration complexity for all other users, and 3) I generally believe that if you need drop down menus, there are better ways to organize your content.

Regarding the last point, consider this. Do 20 different pages need to be accessible at any possible time from the header? Or are some of those pages a little less important, and maybe it'd be fine if they're accessed by first going to a more general top level page in the header.

For example, if you had separate "People", "Sponsors", and "Photos" pages, they could all go under a _single_ top level "Team" page which then has [big links](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Components#link) to the sub pages.

If more people request this feature (please signify your interest with a 👍 ) I can reopen this issue.

I will reconsider this. I think if it's an option, more people will use it (though I still think they maybe shouldn't).

I'll actually try to implement it and see how much complexity it adds. Reference: https://moderncss.dev/css-only-accessible-dropdown-navigation-menu/

title: Host site at root of your-lab.github.io

comments.body:
Hi @jxchen01 If I'm understanding your request... that is how the template currently works. It deploys automatically, without any github actions, to `https://lab-name.github.io/lab-website`. That is the main intended use case. If you're talking about making the website be at `https://lab-name.github.io/` directly, I believe you do it the same way, except you just make sure to name the repo `lab-name.github.io`.

If you are talking about supporting different Jekyll themes in this template, but still keeping the other functionality like auto-citations, that's not something we plan to support.

@vincerubinetti thanks for your swift reply. I don't mean different Jekyll template, just the current one in the template. 

Currenly, I can see the webpage looking good after running through netlify. See https://mystifying-bell-83a659.netlify.app/

But, if I view the webpage directly (see : https://mmv-lab.github.io/), it looks like the picture below:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7811075/121763538-b8208480-caf1-11eb-855e-4d66c7b73ec5.png)

I was thinking maybe netlify did some building steps, but native github page did not? 

Thanks,
Jianxu

I think I figure out the issue. 

It looks like the current template does not support making the webpage available at `lab-name.github.io`, and only supports `lab-name.github.io/lab-name`, due to the base url setting.

for example, if name my repo as "my-lab.github.io", what should I put for `baseurl` in `_config.yaml`? I assume the baseurl refers o the repo name, except cannot use the repo the same as `my-lab.github.io`. 

I am not sure if I made this issue clear. In short, some special setting on the `baseurl` may be needed if users want to deploy the page at `my-lab.github.io`

The template does support hosting it there, but the documentation could be updated to include this option. Simply set `baseurl` to `""`. It is essentially the same instructions as [this section of the docs](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Get-Started#hook-up-a-custom-domain).

> I assume the baseurl refers o the repo name, except cannot use the repo the same as my-lab.github.io.

`baseurl` refers to the part of the url that comes after the root/domain of the url, and before the other pages/folders/sub-divisions of your site, like `github.io/baseurl/about-page`. It doesn't have to do with the repo. `baseurl` is simply what is prepended to all links to images/pages/assets so that they work. Therefore, any time you're hosting your site at the "root" level, like on Netlify e.g. `your-app-preview.netlify.com`, when you have a custom domain e.g. `greenelab.com`, or when you're making a GitHub ["user site"](https://docs.github.com/en/pages/getting-started-with-github-pages/about-github-pages#types-of-github-pages-sites) e.g. `your-lab.github.io`, you just set `baseurl` to nothing.

I will add a new section called something like _Host your site at `your-lab.github.io/`_.

I've added an example of a user site `baseurl` in the docs here:
https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Basic-Editing#config-file

title: Remove tooltip from dom after fading out
body:
Leaving it in the dom (but invisible) can cause layout issues, like the body of the page scrolling horizontally because the tooltip extends past the right border.

Either remove from the dom or set `display` to `none` to remove it from the flow of the document.

title: Move to multiple-output files setup for auto-cite?

comments.body:
A downside of this would be that if you want to display everything in one spot, it'd a bit more verbose:

```
{% include list.html data="sarah-citations" ...
{% include list.html data="tim-citations" ...
{% include list.html data="alex-citations" ...
{% include list.html data="2020-citations" ...
{% include list.html data="2021-citations" ...
```

But... there would be no reason to get rid of the metadata pass-through and `filter="page: tim-member"` method even if we switched to this. So user's could use whatever method was more convenient.

Needs more thought. And input from any users is welcome.

@dongbohu @cgreene @dhimmel I know you're not directly related to this project or the target users, but I would love your thoughts on this if you have time, as I've been stuck in my own head with this template for a long time.

I wonder if it makes sense to think about citations from a tagging point of view where tags could be applied at the item, source, or plugin level, but multiple tags could be applied. In our case, I think we'd apply the `greenelab` tag to everything from my ORCID source as well as anything from the sources plugin. Lab member pages could, by default, display anything with a tag that matches the user id. Then their ORCID source could be configured to assign that tag.

Then our research page could display all `greenelab` tagged publications but the lab member pages would work (and would include all of their papers via ORCID - not just the lab ones).

I've been mulling this over for a while, and I think I've come to the conclusion that it's best the way it is right now, at least for the time being...

There are many different ways we could go about this, but they all feel like they'll get fairly complex. One small example of this is that if we split up the output citations into multiple files, the citation component has to check all of them for the right one to display, or may require an extra `dataset` parameter to specify which file to look in.

Also, listing separate citation sets like 
```
{% include list.html data="sarah-citations" ...
{% include list.html data="tim-citations" ...
```
is a pain, but doable. BUT it also means that you couldn't group them together by year. It would go, for example, "2020 papers, 2019 papers" for sarah's papers then "2020 papers, 2019 papers" for tim's papers. We could have some configuration that says which inputs to merge/map to which outputs, but I feel like that just becomes an order of magnitude more complex, especially for something no one has really complained about yet.

Casey, regarding your example of what you want for greenelab.com, that can still be achieved using the current architecture:

```
{% include list.html data="citations" component="citation" filter="page: , page: casey-greene" %}
```
This will list every citation that has `page: casey-greene` OR no `page` set at all. Then, we just have to make sure every other person who inputs their ORCID puts an eg  `page: alex-lee` field so their citations don't show up in the main list.

body:
Perhaps also consider going to a separate citation output file system, to simplify [this diagram](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8326331/119867215-a765f100-beeb-11eb-8698-2ad4fa337f91.png) into a single layer... Then maybe the `{% include list.html data="citations" component="citation" filter="page: tim-member" %}` solution wouldn't be necessary, and you could just do `{% include list.html data="tim-member-citations" component="citation" %}`. 

Might also make the auto-cite pipeline more clear to the user at first glance. One input file -> one output file. Like `sources-2020.yaml` -> `sources-2020_citations.yaml`

title: Move auto-cite config to global site config?
body: This will allow me to detect automatically where citations are output to, in case the user wants to change it. I think it will also make it a bit less confusing.

title: Pass parameters to auto-cite plugins

comments.body: This is probably overkill. If anyone wants this, comment and I'll reopen. The code in the plugins themselves can specify needed options. The only options the plugins have (in `_config.yaml`) at the moment are what input files they take, which is probably the only thing that might frequently change for users.

body:
Per #70 

> One last thing I might suggest would be to pass through all of the properties defined within the plugin's configuration section to the plugin itself. This way, a plugin could be configured either via a yaml file specific to the plugin or via a section in this file (it would be up to the plugin developer). 

Let's hold off until we have an actual use case. My initial thought was to just put options in the plugins themselves (except for the input filename which the user is more likely to change, and thus pulled out into the config.yaml). Perhaps there might need to be options per each input file. We just don't know what people will need yet.

title: Email obfuscation

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

comments.body: After some consideration, I don't think this is a worthwhile feature to add. To do it without using a [plugin](https://github.com/vwochnik/jekyll-email-protect) (not suppored by gh-pages), would be tons of fragile and ugly liquid code. Marking this as won't fix.

In general, email obfuscation is now considered somewhat futile, as bots have gotten way better at decoding all of our tricks. Crawlers can now run javascript on loaded pages, just as a normal user would, so any de-obfuscating we do for the user, we are also doing for the bot.

It's now recommended to just let your spam filters (which have gotten much better) handle the spam. The most important thing is to not put in additional hurdles for your users, like submission forms, copy-pasting, replacing (e.g. `[AT]`), etc.

Nevertheless, here is a snippet that you can paste into your site to get a javascript-obfuscated email link:
https://jsfiddle.net/x9yp42Lu/show

Additional reading:
https://mailtrap.io/blog/email-obfuscation/
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/748780/best-way-to-obfuscate-an-e-mail-address-on-a-website

body: Spam protection for emails?

title: Tooltips do not always align with text

comments.body:

title: Remove break param from section component
body: Instead having a `break=false` flag to style the first section on a page, just remove and instead filter out blank sections.

title: Allow selecting by id for portrait and post-excerpt components, similar to citation component
body:
The citation component accepts a single `id` field which is used to look up the rest of the info (authors, date, etc) from `citations.yaml`.

The portrait and post-excerpt (side note, let's rename this to just excerpt) could be made to work this way too. That way users could use the portrait component to list members in a manual order, or just display a single member:

`{% include portrait.html id="sarah-smith" %}`

Which would automatically look up all the details from the `_members` collection, without having to do:

`{% include portrait.html name="Sarah Smith" image="some-image.jpg" description="Semantic Engineer" ... %}`

title: Support number types in list filters
body:
The list component has a `filters` parameter where you can specify which items to show, e.g. `filters="age: old"` shows only items who have `age` == `old`.

But right now this only works with string values. There could be many cases where a user wants to use integers or numbers, e.g. `filters="age: 32"`.

For some reason it didn't, although I configured the build command correctly. It's now working after changing the directory, so maybe just making a note?

This is a great template by the way! Thanks so much for all the hard work!

body: In the Netlify instructions, the "Publish directory" needs to be set to `_site`, otherwise there's a 404 error. This should be noted in the "Getting Started" wiki page.

title: Recent refactor regressions and improvements
body:
List of things that broke due to the recent refactor, and ideas for improvements.

- listing items does not go in original order of data array when not grouped by year
- redo gallery component css with respect to the fit option. make `style="square"` option instead.
- **citation component no longer works** (not my fault! due to a single line of a gem package install, see below)
- make small card smaller
- liquid variables are not limited to the scope of the current include. eg if `text` is defined in one file, the next file that happens to be processed can use `text`. check that all variables being used in includes are being reset to some default value before being used. in particular, check the role component
- remove `gem 'github-pages', group: :jekyll_plugins` as it seems to be out of date and causing issues that do not give the latest Jekyll problems. notably, the jekyll `find` filter incorrectly returns an array with this gem install, but returns one item if not. this is what is causing the citation component to fail.

title: Add ORCID to social link component
Add single citation component?
body: We have a research list component, where it lists all research on the site. But it's easy to imagine a user may want to put a citation to a single paper in the middle of a page, say in the middle of a blog post.

title: Enumerate social link, role, and paper link types in data?
body:
I used to have it this way, but then moved it to hard-coding it in the include files themselves.

But due to the TISLab migration, I'm thinking it will be more common than I thought to add custom types, and we should go back to abstracting these types out into yaml, which will be easier for users to understand and edit. The only downside is that it clutters the _data folder with more things the user may not need/want to edit.

I think this again a case of bias towards the way we did it for greenelab.com, where we had very nice/neat categories like undergrad/grad/pi/programmer/etc. But in TISLab, they have more specific titles that should be displayed, like "Bioinformaticist" and "Ontologist" (in fact everyone seems to have a unique title).

title: Make research and resources less opinionated?
body:
We have a team list component that shows all the team members in `/_members` with their picture, name, and role. That, I feel, is going to be pretty standard across the board; what everyone will want.

But while migrating the TISLab to the template, I've realized the template is biased toward the way greenelab.com organizes and separates its information between the "Research" and "Resources" page. Those two things can very much be interwoven and overlapping.

For example, one project might have several papers to show citations for, a big image, a hand-written description, and social media links to github/twitter/etc. This is sort of how [this TISLab page](https://tislab.org/research.html) is at the moment. 

Perhaps there is a more generic way to set up the template so that users can easily set up lists of content, whatever those lists may be.

title: Advanced instructions: How to inline SVGs
body: Took this out of the documentation, because almost no one is going to want to do this. --- You can put SVGs you wish to inline in the `/_includes` folder. Inlining an SVG means putting its source code directly into the page, instead of linking to it as a separate file using an [`` tag](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/img). This allows you to style an SVG (things like fill color, stroke width, etc) from outside of it. This way you can use the same image in multiple different contexts without duplicating it. For example, you can have a single logo file, and color it white when on a dark background, and color it black when on a light background. Try using [`currentColor`](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/css-currentcolor) in your SVG to have it always match the color of text it appears next to. Or if you're more advanced, you can style your SVG with separate CSS where needed. Inlining an SVG also allows contents outside of its bounding viewbox to be shown on the page.

title: Handle case where user builds citations locally more gracefully

comments.body:
My first idea was to use the not operator in the workflow paths like this:

```yaml
on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
    paths:
      - "_data/research.yaml"
      - "!_data/research-output.yaml"
  pull_request:
    paths:
      - "_data/research.yml"
      - "!_data/research-output.yaml"
```

I'm not sure if this actually works as intended (the workflow runs if research was touched, as long as research-output was not also touched).

But then I realized we probably want to have the workflow run any time the input is touched, and overwrite the output always, even if it was also edited by the user. 

In [this GL.com commit](https://github.com/greenelab/greenelab.com/commit/9a87c6b5c92c2d1aae5e1b2556a2cb586cc80320), I put in the option to force push. After some testing, I'll also implement it here. Hopefully it should always overwrite the output, even if the user committed the output, and avoid [this error](https://github.com/greenelab/greenelab.com/runs/2042911600?check_suite_focus=true): 

```
error: Your local changes to the following files would be overwritten by checkout:
	_data/research-output.yml
Please commit your changes or stash them before you switch branches.
Aborting
```

body:
If a user builds citations locally, when they make a PR, github actions will also to build them, causing a conflict in the research-output file.

Handle this better. Perhaps don't let the action run if output has also been touched.

title: Auto-cite plugins for NCBI and Google Scholar

comments.body:
Last I checked, the ORCID api is no longer open to anonymous requests. You need to sign up for an API key. So, each lab that uses this template will need to register their own key.

How I envision this working is that the user signs up for their key, and puts the keys/tokens/secrets in their github repo's secret. Then the auto citations script will receive those secrets (github secrets are available to github actions and scripts running in them) and use them to authenticate with ORCID and pull papers.

Useful other sources besides ORCID:

- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/myncbi/14ygpzWQyXU5Y/bibliography/48560332/public/?sort=date&direction=descending
- https://serpapi.com/google-scholar-author-api

@cgreene FYI, I emailed ORCID about this yesterday. Haven't received a response yet.

> ... On one of your pages, it says that you have to register an application to be able to use the public api, but just testing out some of the end points, it seems like no credentials/authentication is necessary. If I use the public endpoint without credentials, do I (or rather the users of my template) run the risk of being rate-limited or ip-banned from the API? Do you intend to keep the public API open/credential-less forever? If you do recommend creating credentials, do I have to have each of my users set one up for themselves (a somewhat big burden on them), or is it acceptable to have just one set of credentials for the template itself and store that in plain text in the template repo?

Is the goal to have the entire process automated and then generate a PR with new pubs from these sources? There is an existing [R package](https://github.com/jkeirstead/scholar) that can be used to do this with Google Scholar.

title: Support forks after all?

comments.body:
You could document the following options:

1. use GitHub template features to start with a clean commit history but without the ability to automatically pull updates
2. using a clone approach [like Rootstock](https://github.com/manubot/rootstock/blob/2191d929a12a233347ee79c673b8f2971c10e6dd/SETUP.md), which allows for pulling updates, but also requires local git commands and keeps this repo's commit history

Thank you for the insight Daniel. I was hoping there was some obscure Git or GitHub trick that would allow us to get best of both worlds (clean commit history and easy updates). But if you don't know it, it probably doesn't exist!

I'll opt for changing the documentation to just explaining the pros/cons of each, and letting the user decide.

Updated this page to explain the differences:

https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Get-Started

body:
Templates are good because you can get a copy of the repo without all of the commit history. If you're starting a new website for your lab, you don't care about the commit history of the template itself; you care about your own commit history.

However, if you need to pull updates from the template, it's a huge PITA because you [have to manually resolve merge conflicts](https://stackoverflow.com/a/56577320/2180570). Also, you end up getting a bunch of extra commits in the PR from the template anyway, [like this](https://github.com/greenelab/greenelab.com/pull/23).

Perhaps we could explain [here](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/wiki/Get-Started) that you can do a template or a fork, depending on what you want?

Or maybe there's some workaround where you can get easy/automatic merges, and without extra irrelevant commits...

@dhimmel (git expert) @cgreene @dongbohu do you have any thoughts about this?

Deleted. See comment edit history for posterity.

Above is where I will keep/track the testbed code. I wrote this tool to convert and escape the above text into a single-line bash command that writes it to a `testbed.md` file:

https://jsfiddle.net/k0dqngrt/3/show

<details><summary>For posterity (in case the jsfiddle link goes away), the critical part is this</summary>

```javascript
output.value =
  "printf -- '" +
  input.value
  .replaceAll("\\", "\\\\")
  .replaceAll("'", "'\\''")
  .replaceAll("%", "%%")
  .replaceAll("\n", "\\n")
  .replaceAll("\r", "\\r")
  .replaceAll("\t", "\\t") +
  "' >> testbed.md";
```

</details>

Open the fiddle, paste the testbed code from the comment above, copy the generated command, and run that command before the jekyll build command on netlify. Retrigger the latest deploy on the Netlify production site. Then, a `/testbed` url should exist only on `greenelab/lab-website-template`, and only on Netlify (not gh-pages), which is the only place we need this. 

**Live Testbed Page**

https://lab-website-template.netlify.app/testbed

Links to sections on this page are now incorporated into the wiki docs.
