title: Make automatic citations work on master/main?

comments.body: Hi @aditya-sarkar441 - can you put a link to the repo where you're seeing this in the github issue?

GitHub wont automatically build your citations for you unless you are working from a pull request. If you want to work directly on master/main, you'll have to [run the automatic citation script manually](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template#automatic-citations) on your computer.

> GitHub wont automatically build your citations for you unless you are working from a pull request. If you want to work directly on master/main, you'll have to [run the automatic citation script manually](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template#automatic-citations) on your computer.

Ohh I tried to build it on the master. I'll have to then run it manually on my computer first. Thanks !!

> Hi @aditya-sarkar441 - can you put a link to the repo where you're seeing this in the github issue?

Actually, I have reverted that commit. However, the link to our github repo is https://github.com/Mangul-Lab-USC/Mangul-Lab-USC.github.io.
I might be a bit hazy right now, but now that I think about it, we might be able to make it so that it does work on main/master. I'll have to look into it. Renaming this issue to a feature request.

@aditya-sarkar441 : have you considered doing this via a pull request model? That would give you the opportunity to see the results before pushing to master. We generally avoid pushing to master with something that deploys automatically.
@cgreene I didn't know about the pull request model. I'll have to look at it. Thanks !!

Idk how long it's been this way, but the gh-actions workflow does trigger on `push`, which means it should work to push to master/main.

If someone is working from pull requests, the citations will automatically generate. Then when they merge it to main, the citation generation will run again, but the output should be the same, and thus nothing will be committed, and thus there will be no duplicate commit.

I've tested this with pull requests and committing straight to `main` on my own copy of the template, and it seems to work.

Also, i've [updated the gh-actions workflow](https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/blob/main/.github/workflows/update-research.yml) such that there shouldn't be 2 action triggers on pull requests (1 for `pull_request` and 1 for `push`) like it previously did because now `push` only triggers on `main`.

title: General documentation improvement

comments.body: Closed by making the new wiki and also #18

body:
There's a lot to document here, and the readmes and comments can be a bit unruly for people who just want to set up a website quickly.

Here are my cursory thoughts on the situation.

**Short term solution**:  Re-order sections of readme so more important things are first. Also add links where specific files and folders are called out so users follow them to more specific documentation.

**Long term solution**: Make a full "docs" site that is split into pages, and move all documentation there (except for under-the-hood comments on specific lines of code that users aren't meant to read). 

I will have to think a while about the best way to do this, as there are many things to consider.

title: Add note about prepopulating card search input

comments.body: Added to the new wiki.

body: Tell users somewhere that they can append `?search=some search terms` to the url to prepopulate the card search component's input field.

title: Add explicit marker for section breaks
body: Currently, the template tries to be clever and break the page into sections (the alternating white and light-gray backgrounds that span the entire width of the page) based on where `<h1>`'s and `<h2>`'s occur. It's probably better to just have a custom, short, explicit marker, like `<!-- section break -->` where users can tell the template exactly where to put the sections. This would be helpful for where you might want a section break but without a header, such as the Prev/Next Post navigation links at the bottom of a post. It would also be less prone to error.

title: Blog HTML tweaks
body:
- in blog post layout, wrap nav in `<section>`
- in blog-list component, remove first `<hr>`

title: Add flat option for figures
body: Add "flat" option for figures like the gallery component has.

title: Allow spaces in tags
body: Force tag parameter to be array (currently it accepts a string).

title: Research paper search not hiding papers
body: This is a regression bug. Judging by the "# of # papers shown" text, it's filtering them properly. It's just not hiding the actual paper DOM elements.

title: Confusing publication sort order

comments.body:
This is most likely due to the Jekyll/Liquid sorting algorithm sorting the dates as strings rather than numbers. You can see that it shows September (09) first, all the way down to January (01), then December (12) to October (10).

Javascript has the same unfortunate behavior: `[5, 9, 11, 12].sort()` -> `[11, 12, 5, 9]`

Should be fixable by padding a `0` at the start for single digits.

title: Multi-language support

comments.body: Since [the multi-language jekyll plugin](https://github.com/kurtsson/jekyll-multiple-languages-plugin) is [not supported natively by github pages](https://pages.github.com/versions/), we probably wont support it until a lot more people request it. To implement it, we'd have to switch to using a heftier `gh-actions` workflow to manually build the site and commit the results to the `gh-pages` branch, which muddies up things and sorta defeats one of the main purposes of the template: not having a separate `gh-pages` branch and not having a complex CI.

Turns out, the above happened. We are switching to an Actions-based build, which allows us to use any plugins we want. Yay! This plugin is a huge thing to set up, so I don't think we will ever include it in the base template, but I will put it in the docs as a recommended plugin.

body:

title: Add RSS feed

comments.body:
We already enable this by default with this plugin:
https://github.com/jekyll/jekyll-feed

`feed.xml` exists in the root of the built site, for example: 
https://www.greenelab.com/feed.xml

I don't know how RSS or Atom work. I suppose we should put a link to this somewhere? How does one make an RSS link that is useful for users.

Oh cool! I didn't know that. I used a plugin I have in chrome to search for feed links and it didn't find any. Now it worked by providing the feed.xml file. What about a link to that file along with the Twitter, Instagram, etc links?
Oh okay so a link to the feed xml file is all RSS apps/clients/extensions usually need to subscribe? If so that's an easy fix, yes I'll add an RSS social icon at the bottom of the site.

Okay see if your extension picks up the RSS feed on this site:
https://greenelab.github.io/lab-website-template/

I've put an invisible rss tag on the site. I've also put in an actual visible link to the feed in the footer, but commented it out so users can have it there if they want.
Yes, my extension picks up the RSS feed! Awesome!

body: I think it would be nice to have an RSS feed for the site. It could cover the blog, research and resources.

title: Site wide search?

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

comments.body:
Relevant:
https://github.com/algolia/jekyll-algolia

Related:
https://github.com/christian-fei/Simple-Jekyll-Search
https://github.com/chinchang/super-search/

This can be done somewhat easily (though time consuming) using [the method here](https://github.com/christian-fei/Simple-Jekyll-Search#create-searchjson), where you simply iterate through the site's content (the example only includes `site.posts` but you can iterate through all pages content too) using liquid and output/format it as a JSON file that can then be searched by javascript. However, since Google Site Search (already on the 404 page) can probably do a better job (albeit not as nicely integrated), and since no one has actually requested this yet, ~reverting this issue back to just an enhancement~ closing this issue.
This is made further unnecessary by an upcoming PR that makes the google site-wide search into its own component that the maintainer can put anywhere on the site.

body: It may be possible to add an instant site-wide search component [using Lunr](https://learn.cloudcannon.com/jekyll/jekyll-search-using-lunr-js/). This would be a good feature to have if it's easy to implement, ie there is a third party library/plugin to do the heavy-lifting.

title: Additional features

comments.body:
Good suggestions! All but 5) I'm already working on or planning on doing soon.

I haven't done something like 5) before. Do you know a good way to make it work with Jekyll?

I've used internationalization approaches for django before. It looks like the most widely used approach in jekyll is https://github.com/kurtsson/jekyll-multiple-languages-plugin . It builds multiple versions of a site and stores them at paths associated with the language.

It does look like we'll have to use a github action to deploy to pages after running jekyll build ourselves, since github's jekyll doesn't support plugins: https://github.com/marketplace/actions/deploy-to-github-pages

@NatPombubpa I believe with the latest commit I address all of these but 5). If you're satisfied with how I've included/explained the other features you requested, we can close this issue, and I'll open a new issue to track 5) specifically.

I think 5) will have to wait until a bit later, which I think is okay given the availability of Google Translate built into browsers.
Can we create a new issue for internationalization?
https://github.com/greenelab/lab-website-template/issues/5
